overview: Pretend to have a database in S3!
Define the schema in your S3 bucket and point Athena to the bucket
pricing: You can save from 30% to 90% on your per-query costs and get better performance by compressing, partitioning, and converting your data into columnar formats.
$5.00 per TB of data scanned per query
Columnar formats include Apache Parquet and Apache ORC
tables and databases: There aren't actually tables and databases.  Instead they are just metadata definitions that describe the underlying data
The metadata in the table tells Athena where the data is located in Amazon S3, and specifies the structure of the data, for example, column names, data types, and the name of the table.
Databases are a logical grouping of tables, and also hold only metadata and schema information for a dataset.
You have to create a table before you can use Athena
Query results are also stored in S3

definitions.name: Data catalog or metastore
definitions.description: A system for organizing metadata, i.e. descriptions of the tables and columns/types, etc...

definitions.name: Datasource
definitions.description: The dataset + data catalog, aka everything you need to use Athena

definitions.name: Data source connector
definitions.description: Used to get data out of non-S3 locations.  Basically just a special-purpose Lambda

Amazon Athena Federated Query (Preview): You can also search data that isn't stored in S3: relational, non-relational, object, and custom data sources.
